Participant was not sure when to take glasses out of case to start pairing process especially when instructed to look for white LED pulsing
After a failed attempt, participant was able to pair glasses the second time around
Participant adjusting neural band correctly based on instructions
Participant lifting hand to perform hand active hand gestures
Participant is frustrated with timing of screen timeout
Participant notes that screen “keeps going away”
Participant found it difficult to navigate to Hypertrail and notes that swiping up and down is not as simple as swiping left and right using hand gestures
Participant squinted to test whether there was anything else to be potentially perceived aside from screen after I asked what level they were on I’m Hypertrail
Participant notices that hand gestures are not sensitive and any force behind a gesture will result in the same movement in screen. Participant attempting to make a “short” swipe on Hypertrail game.
Participant notices that screen times out even when they are playing game
Participant describes Hypertrail game as helpful in familiarizing themselves with hand gestures but not fun
Participant talks with hands and noticed that MR glasses registered movement as a hand gesture
Participant notices that they have to look at a blank background to see screen clearer
Participant attempting to use hand gestures to navigate back to Whatsapp app
Participant lost visuals of video call and could not navigate back to screen and felt confused on where to “go”
Participant noticed a tone shift in Meta voice when asking similar questions about the same topic
Incorrect date setting on Meta
Participant is focused on audio when asking Meta questions and perceives screen but to a smaller degree
Meta does not accurately read text that participant is looking at
Participant is not impressed with Meta’s ability to answer in depth follow up questions
Meta was able to identify historical painting
Participant notices that Meta gives blurbs of information even if loosely relevant to question that was asked
Participant notices that Meta is redundant and repetitive when asking follow-up questions especially when asking for lists or ideas
Participant notices Meta takes in information from surroundings and generates responses that are not necessarily related to question
Participant is amused by Meta’s tone shifts when responding to questions and comments
Participant wishes that screen would display information with a PowerPoint format and go through talking points instead of having to scroll
Participant believes that if function of MR glasses is to speak aloud to request information, glasses should display information more effectively as users might experiences cluttered screen

Participant notices that Meta delays in answering questions and incorrectly assumes that participant wants to capture a photo. Participant wonders if they are moving hands in a way that prompts registration of hand gesture.
